docs.lead_paragraph: MERCK & COMPANY may be in for a period of disappointing growth at a time when many investors are looking for an earnings breakout by this leading drug company. That, at least, is the position taken in a major new institutional report from David M. Paisley, a vice president and drug company analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. It is a controversial view and one that a number of other analysts do not share.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON WITH the recent conservative gains in Congress, the long-simmering controversy over the Delaney clause, a rarely invoked but potent legal provision that prohibits any cancer-causing additive in food or food products, promises to heat up. For 22 years, the Delaney clause, an amendment to the 1938 Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, has stood inviolate, underpinning the Federal Government's power, through the Food and Drug Administration, to ban from the food supply any chemical that causes cancer in animals or humans. Some of the chemicals that have been taken off the market because of the Delaney clause include DES as an animal feed additive and Violet Dye Number 1. But new voices in Congress and among President-elect Ronald Reagan's advisers, more sympathetic to the food industry's complaints about the provision's absolute prohibition, are pleading for its modification. Equally adamant are consumer health groups and their Congressional allies intent on maintaining the integrity of the clause.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state could tax the mining or extraction of natural resources that were destined for export to other states.

headline.main: Court to Study State Tax on Exported Coal; 'Serious Division' Seen Almost All Shipped Out Other Supreme Court Moves Contractors' Records Air Pollution

docs.abstract: Supreme Court to decide extent to which Federal Government can inspect business records of Federal contractors after lower court ruling that contractors have to make available only information about costs of producing contract items and not records of costs not allocated to specific products
